724891f-a.text:
york Avenue (Avenue A), east side, north from o8th Street. The building on the N.E. corner of 6Bth Street is only slightly in
the picture; it is the old "Century" apartment house.
68th to b9th Streets is the old site of Jones Woods Coliseum (to about 1895, known in 1891 as Empire City Coliseum). 1294-1304 Avenue A, from 69th to 70th Streets, were built after 1902. That block used to be Washington Park. From 70th to 71st Streets may be seen the old cigar factories. The white building, from 71st to 72nd Streets, is Ehe new plant of P. Lorillard Company, built since 1920 on the site of the old Clausen malt house. Everything from o8th to 71st
Streets is about to be demolished.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

724893f-a.text:
Construction of New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College, York Avenue, east side, from o8th to 70th Streets, seen from 67th Street
between First and York Avenues.
July 31, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

724894f-a.text:
New York Hospital and Cornell Mecical College, nearing completion, York Avenue, east side, from 6Bth to 71st Streets, showing also
e8th Street at west side of York Avenue.
On the S.W. corner of 68th Street, adjoining the tennis courts, the old Seidenberg factory has recently been demolished.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

714223f-a.text:
68th Street, west of, adjoiing, and at the north-west corner of fork Avenue. Ihe large buildings in the background are the Cornell University-New lork Hospital buildings.
March 5, 1933
P. L. Sperr, photographer

724890f-a.text:
York Ave., east side, at East 68th Street, showing north of that point the new buildings comprising the New York Hospital and Cornell
Medical College.
1935.
George Jirnek.

724889f-a.text:
York Avenue (formerly Avenue "A"), at the S.W. corner of East 68th Street, showing the easterly and northerly sides of the recently constructed Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases. At the right the photographer shows a westward view on the south side of East o8th Street, towards First Avenue where St. Catherines Park and the Julia Richmond High School
appear.
November 13, 1939
0ift of George Jiranek
New York Public Lirary
Photostat Division

724896f-a.text:
York Avenue, east side, from East 68th to 71st Streets, showing a night view of the New York Hospital and Cornell Medica) College buildings. This photo is hnohtheastward from a rooftop at 430 East 67th Street and shows in the foreground a portion of the recently completed Memorial Hgspital for the Treatment of Cancer.
Fall, 1939
Gif of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library

724888f-b.text:
(1)
York Avenue (Avenue A) at N.E. corner of oBth Street, showing "The Central", an apartment house built in 1902, and about
to be demolished.
Prior to about 1895 this block was occupied by Jones Woods Coliseum, known in its last few years as Empire City Coliseum. The name York Avenue was officially adopted late in 1928.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
York Avenue at N.E. corner of o8th Street, seen from the southwest and showing the other corners.
The new New York Hospital and Co nell Medical College buildinga, nearing completion, occupy the land east of York Avenue from
68th to 70th Streets.
On the S.W. corner, adjoining the tennis courts in the foreground,
the Seidenberg factory has been demolished.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

724892f-a.text:
York Avenue (Avenue A), west side, from o8th to 69th Streets. The third building from the corner, on b8th Street, goes through the block to b9th Street; it used to be a stable belonging to Thomas
Crimmins, Contractor.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

724895f-b.text:
Construction of New York Hospital -- Cornell Medical College, York Avenue, east side, from dBth to 71st Streets, showing S.E.
corner of o8th Street.
This particular view is nearly straight north on York Avenue,
from the roofs on the west side at 6oth Street.
July 31, 1V30.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
New York Hospital -- Cornell Medical College, construction nearly completed, York Avenue, east side, from 68th to 71st Streets, showing S.E. corner of o8th Street. Eleven months
have passed since the preceding view was taken.
The playground of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, shown on the right foregrouno of the preceding view, has now given
place to tennis courts.
June 30, 1V31.
P. L. Sperr.
